content:
Posted: December 28, 2014
												As someone who has played every single Call of Duty game aside from Call of Duty 2 and the new Advanced Warfare. Modern Warfare 3 was something I looked forward too but I had hear bad things about it. So I waited a few years and actually played in this order COD1,UO,WAW,4,BlackOps,MW2,Ghosts,BlackOps2,and finally MW3. I used to hate Call of Duty and it took me a while to distinguish the enjoyment of the singleplayer experiance from the twitch shooter that is the repetitive multiplayer that has really not changed since COD1, if anything it has lost amazing game modes (BehindEnemyLines,BaseAssault). When Bad Company 2 came out I basically said the hell with COD, BUT I came back to the franchise for what it does right, the enjoyable rollercoster that is the playable movie of the Campaign. I loved the story in ModernWarfare and the trilogy is pretty well wrapped up with MW3. A lot of questions about the story are answered if the ending itself is a little lackluster for all the work you have gone through in the previous games to get to the ultimate showdown of two dewds. Anyway no spoilers but the campaign was pretty well paced and enjoyable with some great set peices and the feel of WW3 was captured as well as this old engine can capture. I would not recommend this game to anyone to start with, nor if you are not invested into the ModernWarfare trilogy story etc. For fans of the series though its a must, to bring the story arc to a rather thrilling conclusion. I still think the Black Ops games have been the best COD games since COD united Offensive and the original MW. Hope this helps you guys. It gets a cautious recommend from me for fans of the franchise and story.

number of helpful: 84 of 110 people (76%) found this review helpful16 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: October 21, 2015
												Call of Duty: Modern Warfare 3 has already shipped and millions of eager fans are already playing. By now you already know whether or not you are going to be getting this game, which makes this review rather pointless. What can I possibly say that you haven't already heard; what tidbit of exclusive information can I pass on that you already don't know. It's not like Activision has been keeping their games a secret. I guess all that's left for me to do is share my personal experience with the game, what the designers did right, what they did wrong, and let the chips falls where they may.There are so many Call of Duty installments out there it's hard to keep them straight when it comes to the story. Modern Warfare 3 is the direct sequel to Modern Warfare 2, which was the direct sequel to the original Modern Warfare, so in essence, this is the third installment in the trilogy. We have our familiar cast of characters, Soap, Price, and Nickolai, and a new recruit, Yuri, the Russian member of your team who will be at the other end of your controls for most of the missions. Makarov is still up to his old tricks in his quest for global domination. After his failed attempt in Modern Warfare 2, Makarov has basically initiated WWIII with an assault on the USA as well as a massive simultaneous terrorist strike using bio-weapons.Call of Duty: Modern Warfare 3 assaults you with its overpowering presentation, from the opening moment where your Humvee is taken out by an RPG in NYC and a building explodes and comes raining down on you until the bittersweet final boss encounter. Despite its aging graphics engine, the game maintains a fluid 60fps while pumping out graphics that are easily on par with Battlefield 3. Some scenes border on photorealistic, and when you set the entire thing in motion with sweeping cinematic camera moves things get real crazy real fast. The level of complexity in the level design and the amount of detail is staggering and surprisingly, especially in the multiplayer maps, and it only gets better on the PC.The sound mix is completely immersive with a stirring soundtrack that will fuel your adrenalin, great voice acting and in-game chatter, and some fantastic sound effects for all the weapons and explosions. The sampling rate has been boosted so these guns have never sounded better or more realistic, and there are plenty of shellshock and disorientation effects that will leave you breathless. Sadly, the whole presentation falls a bit short of console greatness since I'm not playing on a home theater, but with a good set of speakers or surround headphones, Modern Warfare 3 will still blow you away - just not as much.The game kicks off in New York City and thanks to pre-release coverage, you've probably already seen most of the first two chapters that has you destroying an enemy jamming tower then heading out into the harbor to cripple a Russian sub and launch its missiles on its own fleet. From there you'll need to rescue Soap from a safe house, then protect the Russian president and his daughter in one of my favorite levels that had me feeling like Harrison Ford in Air Force One. Then it's off to Sierra Leone, London, Somali, Paris, and Berlin as you try to foil Makarovs plans for world supremacy.Without a doubt, this is the best story in the trilogy, with each mission feeding into the next or at least having some parallel story thread. There are no missions stuck in there just because they are "cool", but every mission is extremely cool, a Hollywood set piece worthy of a Michael Bay, Jerry Bruckheimer joint venture. The pacing is frantic, the energy and action nonstop, and yet they manage to work in moments of butt-clenching suspense when you are sneaking through enemy territory and one false move or loud noise can end your mission.The 15-part story, divided into three acts, will take you about 8 hours to complete on Normal and about 10 on Hard. Most of the Steam achievements are divided up into the story, completing each chapter, completing the game on the various difficulty levels, and there are even a few skill challenges that are mission specific and quite fun to tackle. Of course, the hidden intel are back; 46 in all and some are quite diabolical. I have mixed emotions on these egg hunts, since it really takes you out of story to have your men yelling for you to advance and you're scouring every nook and cranny for a blue monitor.Modern Warfare 3 brings back Spec Ops, a great co-op experience you can share online or local split-screen playing Survival mode or Mission mode. Survival mode basically puts you into levels and throws endless waves of enemies at you until you die, so your score and rank is based on how long you can stay alive. Things get downright evil when they start throwing combos like Juggernauts, Dogs, Choppers, and Bomb Squads at you.But for most of the world, Modern Warfare 3 is all going to boil down to the competitive multiplayer and frankly, it doesn't get any better than this. There is a large selection of maps and modes including fan favorites like Team DM, Sabotage, Domination, HQ, CTF, and Search and Destroy, but the game gets exponentially better once you play the new modes like Team Defender and Kill Confirmed. Team Defenders is basically CTF but you have no place to return the flag. There is only one flag and you merely run around with the flag while your team tries to protect you. The team who can carry the flag to the target limit win.Sledgehammer has taken the franchise back to its roots, or at least as far back as Call of Duty 4; the original Modern Warfare. Gone are all the unrealistic gameplay devices like Nukes and the Commando perk. Modern Warfare 3 is making the game more personal with a focus on close-quarters combat. Sniper rifles have been retuned, and air-support has been downsized. Modern Warfare 3 is all about teamwork and getting back to the good old days of Team DM; statistically, the most played multiplayer mode in Call of Duty.The Perks system hasn't changed all that much. You still choose three then complete the various challenges to earn the Pro version. What has changed, for the better in my opinion, are the perks themselves. They just seem to make more sense now, and they all contribute to a more balanced and team-focused gameplay experience. Unrealistic perks like Commando, OMA, Last Stand, and the game-ending Tactical Nuke are now only a bad memory.Modern Warfare 3 is going to offer all your favorite weapons and nothing much has changed when it comes to selection or balance. New for Modern Warfare 3 is the ability to rank up your weapons through continued use, so the more you use a gun, the better you get with it.Modern Warfare 3 also improves upon the existing Prestige system. After you reach the end of the 80th level and hit the Prestige button you get taken to the new Prestige Shop where you can choose from eleven different rewards. With each prestige you get a Prestige Token to spend in the Prestige Shop on whatever you wish as well as your complimentary Prestige Icon.Modern Warfare 3 is a shining example of refinement and improvement. It's familiar, sure, but here familiarity doesn't breed contempt, just respect and reward for those who've dedicated so much time to the series. And for new players, it's the perfect starting point, more accommodating and encompassing than ever. The series has always been renowned for elements like the excellent sound design, the gloss, polish and compulsion of its gameplay, but with Modern Warfare 3, Infinity Ward and Sledgehammer have created a game that not only lives up to the brand hype but exceeds it.

Finally, a game package from great value: a campaign spot on, many and various Spec Ops, sixteen maps and numerous game modes of implanted mechanical magazines that work. Quality and quantity in short.

content:
Posted: April 14, 2015
												Single-player: Except for the weird prologue, I thought that the story was a ton of fun. If it gets boring, pick a harder difficulty (and have fun dying if you picked one too hard). The fact that each mission isn't totally reset when you die is a lovely perk that (while I should have expected, I didn't) made the game much more enjoyable. The special ops missions are a lot of fun, but a few things should be pointed out:1). It can take a while to find people to play with, so if you don't have patience, bring friends.2). You can't play cross - server special ops with your friends, so if you have a Mac and your friends have Windows, you're out of luck.3). If you do have a Mac ( and Windows - loving friends), play multi - playerMulti - Player: A ton of fun to play once you can participate in the games in any meaningful amount (meaning that you don't get killed every time you poke your head out of the hole you're hiding in). However, a few tips: 1). There aren't any set noob maps, so if you're new, this can be frustrating. But, if I made it (and I sucked a TON at first), you can make it (unless you suck more than I did).2). There aren't any rooftop vantages or upper floor rooms that are protected to the point when sniping becomes a good option for new players. (Some maps don't have ANY  very elevated sniping spots) You have to be good (i would hesitantly say VERY good) in order to run and gun with a sniper, so avoid this unless you have a lot of practice in the single - player (harder difficulties) or in other games3). Many of the game modes don't have anyone playing them. The two that i've found to be most frequented by players are Team Deathmatch and Kill Confirmed. Others are played, of course, but it will be harder to find a full room. 4). As always, playing with friends is a ton of fun, and if some of them are experienced, all the better. If you don't have friends, quit playing games and find some :). JK. I don't have friends either.A fun game in the FPS category, and I had a lot of fun playing. However, patience and time are necessary for the full experience. Despite the restrictions at first, the hackers (there weren't that many, actually, but they were annoying), and the limited gamemodes, I enjoyed my time, so I'll give this a (7/10).Actually, on second thought, I've remembered how much fun I had playing hide and seek with a bunch of guys (armed with Five - Sevens), playing arrow - chicken with C4 and Frag Grenades, and amusing my friends by making ridiculously macho comments, then dying a second later by more attentive players. So, I'll give it an 8/10. Always remember: If at first you don't succeed, you probably never will. Give up now and save yourself some trouble :).

content:
Posted: March 18
												Where to start. I finished the campaign a little less than an hour ago, thereby completing the journey that I've been on with these characters starting with the first Modern Warfare, a decade past in 2007. It's been quite a ride and after this last one, I find myself emotionally drained and deeply satisfied. The narrative was engaging as always, with its myriad twists and turns backed up with solid gameplay and gunplay. A wonderful cast of characters; old and new, friends and enemies alike. The visuals are nice and detailed, from the character models to the environments, even in 2017.Infinity Ward started something magical with MW and to see it's completion is bittersweet for me. Gaz, Roach, Soap, Price, Yuri, Sandman, Nikolai... and others I'm probably forgetting in the slight daze that I'm in, never has there been a more colorful rogue's gallery of lovable heartbreakers and lifetakers.I will miss you.

I have only seen one hacker in my time online, the servers will slightly lag every now and then, and I know it's not just me.In retrospect, this game is great, despite it's flaws, it is still a game well worth the money you have to pay for to get it.

content:
Posted: May 3, 2015
Pros:The same great action of the previous games. Lots of multiplayer options.Cons:Not much changed since Call of Duty: Modern Warfare 2. Single-player campaign is confusing for people who haven't played the other Modern Warfare games. Modern Warfare 3 picks up where Modern Warfare 2 left off. I mean, exactly where it left off. Russia is at war with America, Makarov is at large, Soap's injured, and everything is blowing up. If you didn't play Modern Warfare 2, which served as a decent starting point and didn't require the first game to understand it, you won't have any idea about what's going on, and the game doesn't do much to get you up to date. It feels very much like the third movie in a trilogy, and the second movie ended on a cliffhanger. The gameplay, both in single player and multiplayer modes, is identical to that of Modern Warfare 2. You can carry two weapons and two types of grenades (one offensive, one special) at one time and you have to hide behind cover and employ tactical savvy in your approach firefights if you want to kill your enemies. It's an established and functional style that captures modern, "realistic" first-person shooter games. If you get hit a few times, you need to hide behind cover until you heal, or a few more stray bullets can kill you. It's unforgiving, but balanced.Multiplayer is the big draw of Modern Warfare 3, and it pays off just as much as it did in the other games in the series. There are the same seemingly endless customization options, with an experience system and the ability to build your own class with different weapons and abilities. The killstreak system from previous games has been refined into a points-based system that gives players more balance. Instead of getting points for each kill, players can choose Assault, Support, and Specialist modes that give them different rewards. Assault is the traditional killstreak system, where you get new abilities like missile strikes for more kills in a single life. Support counts your kills and other actions between lives, constantly moving up and giving you support-based abilities like UAVs. Specialist gives you more perks for your kills, instead of new weapons it effectively turns you into a super-soldier who's faster, stronger, or able to take more damage.The multiplayer options offer a benefit over Battlefield 3, which only has six cooperative missions compared to over a dozen in Modern Warfare 3. Competitive play is pretty evenly matched, with leveling in Modern Warfare 3 universal and steadily unlocking weapons and skills and leveling in Battlefield 3 and rewarding your class as you play it. The big difference between the two games is that Battlefield 3 has vehicles, which can change the nature of a game dramatically. To go to extremes, Modern Warfare 3 is more suitable for Counter-Strike fans, while Battlefield 3 is more suitable for Halo fans, but the distinction between the two modern combat games are far smaller than the rift between the two classic shooters.Modern Warfare 3 is a solid follow-up to Modern Warfare 2 and Black Ops, and if you loved those games you'll love this one. It doesn't change anything big, and the single-player campaign wraps up a story with most of the exposition lodged in previous games, but it offers a great multiplayer experience and a solid, if predictable and occasionally frustrating, single-player experience.

content:
Posted: November 30, 2016
												The game in general is great fun. The Single player is good, especially if you've played the two predecessors, though I actually played this campaign before I played the Modern Warfare 2 campaign. You'll have your 4-6 hours of adrenaline pumping action or even more if you play it on hardened or veteran (which I recommend that you do). But wait, there is more. Just like in Modern Warfare 2 you have Special Operations with several additional missions to go through, either on your own or with a friend. A new addition in Modern Warfare 3 however is the Survival Mode in which you fight to survive onslaughts of enemies thrown at you, wave after wave.Moving on to the multiplayer. I have circa 500 hours played and it's great. This was my first Call of Duty multiplayer experience and I've loved every minute of it. A big issue however is the abundance of hackers and cheaters which is proven to cause general anxiety, flying objects (not by me personally) and hairloss. This can however be mitigated with buying the multiplayer map packs, mainly because the majority of people who decide to cheat can't afford these.Another issue is the price of DLC. I have bought the 3 multiplayer map packs myself on sales at insane prices. I wish they would have released a complete edition or similar, but no. The last con I'd like to point out are the limited graphic settings. However, you can alter the config. files to fix this. There are several guides online if you're unsure about what to do. There is also an officially backed Field of View-changer which won't get you banned.Tl;dr: The game is great fun and one of the best multiplayer shooters I've played in recent years. If you're tired of Counter-Strike or the later installments of Call of Duty, give this one a try, you won't be disappointed. Just remember to get the map packs to avoid the cheaters.

content:
Posted: May 23, 2016
												I don't usually write reviews about games I cannot recommend, but I believe people need to be warned about this.MW3 was the first Call of Duty I've bought, and it will also be the last. If you want to know why, read on.I have over 600 hours played in the multiplayer, which you cannot see because Steam uses two different apps for this game, one for singleplayer and one for multiplayer. And I don't even know why, because much of it was more frustrating than fun. But I think I have experienced the best and the worst this game has to offer, and can tell other people with good conscience what they will get from this.CoD games have a history of receiving flak from dedicated FPS players for being bad games despite their popularity on consoles. Since this was my first time playing a game of the MW series, most of this, such as "60$ map pack", didn't apply to me. I went into it with an open mind free of prejudice, and here is what I got:At first, the game is quite fun. It is polished, the controls are sharp and responsive, the sound and keybinds work as they should. None of the things that usually accompany console ports such as mouselag or unbindable keys, it would seem. However, the FoV is locket at 60, so any dedicated player is forced to rely upon a certain 3rd party tool to fix this issue.SingleplayerThe single-player campaign is passable. In typical CoD style, you usually enter an area and have enemies respawn indefinitely until you move to the next checkpoint. Ignoring that the most efficient way to play is to rush through instead of actually fighting, the FPS key elements such as gunplay and movement are solid. The game is, however, heavy on scripted sequences and quicktime events. Despite being more of an old-school FPS player, I wasn't too bothered with the modern stuff such as bloody screen, regenerating health and checkpoints.MultiplayerSince most people play CoD exclusively for the multiplayer, this will be the major part of my review. And boy, you are in for something.Now, as stated above, the game itself plays pretty well. Unfortunately, the multiplayer part is plagued by a number of massive issues which outnumber the good parts a thousandfold.First off, this game is designed all around the famous skinner box. It compels you to play, even in times you don't really want to or are not having a good time. What this translates to ingame are a number of psychological features that would be an absolute no-go for any good gamedesign, such as leveling up, unlocking guns and similar. I'm sure the developers could make a game that was actually good instead of forcing people to play through psychology... if they actually tried. But as it is, MW3 is designed to keep you addicted for a certain amount of time, after which it starts to get boring quickly. That timeframe, who could have guessed, is a few months, just enough until before the release date of the next title in the CoD series.Then, there is this weird feature that is called "lag compensation". Now, the feature in inself is nothing new and has been seen in games for years. But in the way it is implemented here it actually gives players with bad connections an huge advantage over players with good connections. Dying the very instant you cross a corner before even seeing anyone, only to see your opponent had seconds of spraying your helpless body is a frequent occurrence. Since I had a fast connection, I would suffer massively from this feature, to the point where I had to actively limit my internet speed to be on an even playing field with everyone else.Now here is the main part: the multiplayer is infested with cheaters. Like you wouldn't believe. We UT and Quake players always used to make fun of CS for its amount of wallhackers, but MW3 is in an entirely different league. Cheaters are so prevalent in MW3 that finding a single game without a cheater is practically impossible, and I'm not exaggerating. Wish I was. More often than not, there would be 2-3 cheaters in any single game you come across.And I'm not talking about simple wallhackers. I'm talking about guys with godmode on, unlimited ammo, can kill you the very moment you spawn from the other end of the map through all walls and objects and even teleport all players on the map high in the air to fall to their death in 10 seconds intervals. Or outside the playable map, to have them stand around, being unable to do anything until the torture ends.There is no working anti-cheat feature in MW3 whatsoever. What is worse is, MW3 is designed in such a way that not only it is impossible to punish cheaters, it even encourages them through the use of a lobby system. There are no servers where such players could be banned, or even a vote system to kick them. If you end up with one cheater in a 20 player match, the only solution would be for the other 19 players to abandon the game and leave, only to be replaced with new unsuspecting victims until the cheater is satisfied to his heart's content.One of the players in the lobby would always end up as the host for a match. There used to be a 3rd party program which let you analyze the IP connections in the game and, with the help of another filtering program, you could deny certain IP adresses to connect to your PC, essentially banning cheaters from your games if you were fortunate enough to be chosen as the host. The sad part is that MW3 is so infested with cheaters that using those tools is practically mandatory if you want at least a few of your games to be actually playable. What's worse is that there are a number of players who also abused this. They would ban anyone they felt like banning, for reasons such as killing them, saying something they didn't like, using a weapon they didn't like or choosing to play in a way they didn't like.That, however, was before cheaters had hacks that could force them to become host of their games, every time. Now, cheaters were not only able to kill any players with the push of a button, but they had total control over their games, and gave everyone else a ridiculously high ping in the process.Cheaters are everywhere and anywhere, and it is impossible to avoid them. Playing MW3 online without being a cheater yourself is like bringing a knife to a tank fight. They turn the multiplayer into an unplayable mess, and the developer/publisher refuse to adress this problem. It's like they don't give a damn, once you've paid your 60$ you've "done your duty" and are now expendable, thank you very much come again next year with your wallet. I know, fire-and-forget port of a console game, but still. While theoretically it's the players ruining the game, the fact that those companies even fail to do as much as acknowledge a problem of such a degree that it turns a game into a basically nonfunctional product is borderline fraudulent. I refuse to support companies that treat their customers in such a way, and will never buy something from Actvision again. I gave them a chance to earn my trust (and money), and they blew it as hard as you possibly can. A shame, really, I liked the game in itself, and I wanted to play it, as you can no doubt tell from my 600 hours, but problems of such a scale completely ruin every aspect of it and turn it into nothing more than a♥♥♥♥♥♥fest.TL;DR: There are two kinds of people playing MW3 online: cheaters, and masochists. If you are neither, I suggest you stay as far away from this game as you possibly can, or you're in for a lot of frustration.

content:
Posted: January 27
												Call of Duty Modern Warfare 3 was my first-ish Call of Duty that led me into the Series.When this Game first came out it used to be 80€ on Steam and 60€ in our local Store. Save to say I did not buy it from Steam. Since this Game has 3 Sections, my review also will be divided by 3.Singleplayer:The Singleplayer Campaign was in my experience a nice addition to the second Modern Warfare and I did enjoy it alot. It took me 10 Hours to complete it on Normal Mode, which is about the Average amount of time for a Triple A Singleplayer Game.Co-op:I'm not quite sure if Modern Warfare 2 had a Co-op Mode but this one is alot of fun that means, if its working. You can play Survival with a friend together, defending waves of enemies coming in & with each Wave survived you become a more powerful weapon, however the enemies will also be more powerful. Whilst this Mode is alot of fun it also is very broken as it comes out of sinc within the first 5 Minutes making this Mode almost unplayable.Multiplayer:As I Already said, this was one of my first Call of Dutys to get into the Series and also the Reason to get a Steam Account. Before I bought Modern Warfare 2 (2 Weeks before this MW3 got released) I had not heard of Steam before.The Multiplayer was at the time for me alot of fun especially with friends, I have spent over 1000 hours of Multiplayer Game time together and did enjoy my time.However for nowerdays standards the Multiplayer is not good anymore for the following Reasons:-No Dedicated Servers -No FOV Slider-No Anti Cheat (yes VAC is enabled but I dont think anybody gets banned anymore)-Mainly Hackers online-Hacked Lobbies (they can't get you banned)I surley did get my money out of the Game but I still do not recommend it as of nowerdays standards.I only recommend this Game for people that want to play the Singleplayer Campaign and see what happens after Modern Warfare 2. But do yourself a favour and buy it from a Keywebsite for 4€ Because even on Sale this Game is to expensive for what it gives you. If you are looking for a good Call of Duty on PC I do recommend you to get Black Ops 2 as it was the last good Call of Duty that still is to this day banning cheaters and having dedicated servers + a build in fov slider.

content:
Posted: July 12, 2016
Call of Duty: Modern Warfare 3 a.k.a MW3 is one addictive beast of a game.Just like most COD games, it has 3 primary segments: Campaign: The story mode in this game continues from where MW2 left off. In all honesty, everything is pretty much predictable besides some small twists and turns. It's all linear. Although, the characters are very iconic and the voice acting accompanied by Hollywood-like direction do make it a pleasant one-time play.Special Ops: The spec-ops mode is Infinity Ward's alternative to the immensely popular Zombies mode offered in Treyarch COD games. However, instead of Zombies the player(s) complete co-op missions and fight waves of AI-based humans. Imo, it's hell lot of fun when played with friends.Multiplayer: The most important and most played segment in a COD game has always been the multiplayer. MW3 has a great deal of weapon variety and introduces players to the new Specialist strike package, which replaces kill streaks with additional perks. Oh, and the perks are nearly exactly the same as in MW2. Yes, there are lots of noob-tubing weapons in this game as well - Launchers and spray shotguns, but most players now play a lot more sensibly, especially in modes like Search and Destroy. The ACR 6.8 is undoubtedly the most dominant weapon in the game, given it has pretty much no recoil, great iron sights and the best range in class. Do not misjudge me by the hours you see on this account. I have been playing this game for more than 4 years and to say the least, I certainly have clocked in 2500+ hours in the multiplayer aspect alone.Conclusion:+ Variety in weaponry+ Sniping gives chills+ Well balanced perk system+ Great maps+ No micro transactions (The last COD to do so)- Hit detection has flaws- Campaign doesn't live up to expectations- Half the achievements require you to purchase DLC (For the 100% achievement freaks)P.S. The review is written with a general perspective. New players may not want to buy the game at a high price since there are many hackers in here and it just wouldn't be worth it. You can find clean lobbies too, but not as easily.

There are few advance cheats but mostly the one all favorite cheat is only WallHack.IF You still intend to play the multiplayer I advice to never watch KillCams otherwise You will get to know how some people are ‘better’ than You are – this is the only way to avoid frustration. Have fun if You can.

content:
Posted: July 2, 2016
												Where to start... Okay, so this COD game is a good few years old but speaking as a person who has played most (not all) COD's I can honestly say this is in the top 3 of the BEST when it comes to Multiplayer. I'd even go so far as to say it's in the top 5 online FPS games ever! It really had/has everything. Back in the day I put in around 2000-3000 hours on the ps3 version, 700-800 hours on the 360 version..so as you can tell I was a fan of this game lol. Well, I had a few pounds going spare so decided to pick it up in the Summer sale to put in a few more hours of this once amazing game. Sadly, this is no longer possible, due to the emense amount of hackers that seem to have taken over the online game. When I purchased the game I was expecting a few hackers to be online as is with most online games. However, it seems impossible to find any matches/games on the weekends and week nights that are not filled with hackers and i'm not talking about "Oh, he shot me through smoke. He must be a hacker". I am talking hackers that leave other gamers in no doubt they're hacking and in a few occasions gloat about it. Maybe I have way to much time on my hands but i decided to keep a diary of the hackers hopefully stopping players, like myself, who want to buy this game to relive the amazing online game from buying this game. Here is a record of 12 consecutive TDM games on Friday the 1st of July 2016.    Game 1: 2mins after a fresh game started the nuke warning was given with no player having killed more than 5 players.Game 2: A user named HDK had a 30-0 kill streak. On every single kill cam he was seen looking at the ground and shooting. Half way through the match he was seen flying through the air and killing people. Left the que. Game 3: Joined a game and found 3 players flying around killing people. Game 4: No noticeable hackersGame 5:  Half way through the next game two players joined called HDK and ----. HDK (from one of the previous games) started flying around shooting people while the other is seen, on kill cam, following people through the walls and shooting them with the cursor locked onto their head.Game 6: Started the game was everybody died within 10 seconds. On each kill cam you see a player randomly shooting into the air and killing a player with each shot. Left gameGame 7: 2 players started flying around shooting other team members. Left game and logged off for 3-4 hursGame 8: Started playing TDM: No hackers noticed Until last part of the match when a player joined and started getting all headshot kills. On inspection of the kill cam you can see his cursor moving instantly to the enemies head while behind walls. As soon as the enemy becomes visible they were instantly dead. Left before the end.  game 9: 2 players from our team and 1 from the opposition started flying around the map. Game 10: Once again found myself in the game with the user named TDK. As normal he was flying around shooting people. Game 11: Joined a game halfway through and started getting killed every time I respawned.The player who kept killing us was stood fancing the wall shooting every now and thenGame 12: 2 players from my team were flying around killing. As you cans ee the game is now officialy at the mercy of hackers. DO NOT BUY unless you plan on using single mode only or know a trust worthy team you plan on playing against.

content:
Posted: April 30, 2013
												MW3 is the game when COD went downhill. It's pretty much a rehash of MW2 with some really bad design choices. The amount of improvements is minimal and they even managed to make the game look worse than the previous games.PlotWhat do i mean?Well, COD games have been linear shooters since their very first game. This game is no exception. I personally don't see a problem in that. That said, usually a COD game has a relatively good story and this one is far from it.The game events start right after MW2. US is pushing russians back to the cost line. Your first mission is in NYC. You hijack a mother submarine and use its rockets to sink all the remaining russian forces. You see what i mean now? Original's COD motto was "no one fights alone", but starting MW3 it's more like "one man army". That's pretty much how the whole game is played. You literally rambo your way through the whole game.The next mission has the russian president flying to Hamburg to sign the peace treaty, but his plane gets hijacked by terrorists (Makarov). President gets taken hostage and it triggers another war. I suppose the terrorist attack would make it seem as if Germany was the aggressor.Makarov plants chemical attacks in major european countries and the next day Russia starts invading Europe. Russia, a country that supposedly just lost a war with US in MW2. Where do they find the manpower and the gear to start another war? They do very good by the way. In a matter of few days they reach Paris.Meanwhile Makarov is working hard on getting nuclear launch codes from the russian president. He starts searching for the president's daughter, who happens to be in Berlin (she escaped the plane was it was hijacked). A group of like 20 men is sent to get her out. They fail to do that and Makarov gets the girl. But in the end they somehow manage trail them back to their hideout, where they rescue both the president and his daughter. The next day the war ends.The war started on 4th October and ended by 14th October.I would say that it was a very mediocre way of representing WW3. It doesn't go that much in depth and it has very big plot holes.Second of all, it was mostly about special ops forces rather than your regular front line soldier. Majority of the time you were fighting against your odds. The enemy would outnumber and you would still come out as a victor. As i said, this is a rambo game. The previous games had that, but they kept it in check. This game takes it to a whole new level. It just ruins an otherwise great trilogy.I suggest anyone who is interested in more to check this link:https://northatlanticblog.wordpress.com/2014/02/01/modern-warfare-vs-real-warfare-part-3-of-3/MultiplayerThe multiplayer is pretty much the same, with one big elephant in the room.First of all, it's pretty much a map pack, reskin, call it whatever you want. Pretty much all the things in MW3 are part of MW2. It has a few changes here and there. For example now there are 3 killstreak trees. You can choose a normal killstreak tree that gives killstreaks for kills but nullifies the score if you die, or a support tree that gives killstreaks but doesn't nullify your kill count upon death. Finally there is the specialist tree that gives you perks for every few kills. Also, i think the other big change is that weapons have a level and that's how you earn attachments now. But that's about all - everything else was pretty much copy and pasted from the previous games. It's very low effort.The elephant i was talking about is the spawn system. They completely messed it up by making enemies spawn right behind you after killing them. It was nicknamed as the revenge spawn system among the community.Example #1Example #2Example #3In the past COD games, maps had certain zones where you could spawn in. The problem with that is that it can create spawn killing. They were trying something new, but they failed. I personally really loved MW2 and since it's pretty much the same game, i would have played it to death, but this thing really makes it unplayable.That makes you realize how important stuff like maps, spawns or balance are in multiplayer games. SurvivalIn MW2, spec ops were kind of hit or miss. At times i would like the mission. At times i would not. There were certain types of levels in spec ops that required you to hold out for a certain amount of waves. Those were the ones that i really liked, and in MW3 they decided to make a separate mode out of it, named as Survival, except that the amount of waves is infinite and you can buy weapons, perks, killstreaks.It's amazing. I spent most of my time playing MW3 in Survival. It's really the only thing you should be playing if you are getting this game. It's a worthy contender to Treyarch's zombies and unlike zombies it offers a vast amount of levels to play in. The levels are taken directly from multiplayer - the maps. There are 16 maps in multiplayer, so you get 16 levels for survival.ConclusionWell, like i said, MW3 was pretty much a big disappointment. If you are gonna get it, get it only for coop mode. Also remember that the graphics are bad. In fact, i actually had a marathon, where me and my friends would play the modern warfare franchise. MW3 actually managed to look worse than the other 2.On a side note, i want to add that the development team that was working on Call of Duty games, Infinite Ward, had a big argument with the publisher and about 46 IW employees left the company. That was shortly like 6 months after MW2's release. All those people formed a new company named Respawn Entertainment, which is responsible for Titanfall.The writer for the game - Jesse Stern, was also replaced with somebody else. So really, MW3 isn't even a COD game to be honest. Every body who worked on the franchise that we loved were not part of MW3. That's all i had to say.

content:
Posted: September 7, 2016
												You know, I love this game to be honest. And most of the Call of Duty games were great. I've played them since they were on pc originally and I was young, and then later on xbox with friends. It gets a lot of hate now, and I'll admit they're far from the greatest games ever, but I'd say the whole series gets an 80% at least, for doing what they did right. There's really some cool, classic concepts in these games. Games are evolving and it seems like poor Call of Duty is struggling to keep up. Just wait till 2019, VR CoD is on it's way... But I had some great times with these games, I haven't tried multiplayer yet, but I didn't really buy it for that. I bought it for the campaign(which isn't the best but it's enjoyable) and mostly for the survival and missions tab. I'll get some friends to get this too, and we'll play one day again hopefully. On that note I am worried. Mostly because of controller support.. Or, the lack there of. Seriously. A triple AAA title designed for the xbox controller, has no controller support? That's ridiculous. I understood even up to WaW. But after that one, you guys need damn controller support. Serious♥♥♥♥ingly please. And also, I realize that If I were say to wanna play co-op with my friend or girlfriend, I would have to buy the anniversary again to enjoy most of the titles. Honestly, i don't mind that. Because on sale the price is what i'd expect for the content. But I would love splitscreen honestly. I know that'll never happen but it was on the originals and a big concept, too. Surely it wouldn't be that hard... Other than those two issues, which I'm only expecting and even demanding controller support, I'm happy with this port (i think it's a port, right?) so far. I hope CoD makes that come back and starts to be good again. I would go as far as to say this may be one of the most epic series of fps games ever. But also in some ways it's like Battlefield for pansies or Counter Strike for the mentally handicapped. So I guess that if you've read up to this point you're pretty interested in the title and obviously you know that's it ultimately up to you to decide the quality of this game for your reality. I would like for you to buy it though. And then come play some co-op survival with me.

content:
Posted: November 11, 2015
												This is an old game, but still one of the best in the series. Along with the two previous Modern Warfare titles, arguably the pinnacle of the Call of Duty series.In no particular order, some of the stand-out points: Outstanding sound design: explosions and guns feel like the real thing, something later titles in the series have lost. Superbly paced campaign [for maximum value/enjoyment, play the previous titles first] Variety in terms of roles within the campaign setting, and also in terms of locale. Spec Ops! Something I wish later titles would bring back. So much fun when played in co-op. Survival is also a lot of fun (wave based survival game). Awesome multiplayer (great hit detection, excellent maps, decent weapon variety, solid look and feel to weapons)That being said... there are some issues. A lack of dedicated servers can mean extreme P2P lag, and unfortunately the multiplayer is rife with hackers :/ it really does take all the fun out of it.If you enjoy Survival and Spec Ops modes, I would suggest buying the DLC packs as well, since they add missions and game modes on top of the already impressive package.Overall, highly recommended. I love this game <3

content:
Posted: September 23, 2015
												An Epic conclusion to the Epic Saga!The modern Warfare series has come a long way ever since the first modern warfare released in 2006. It has evolutionized the genre and changed the way we play and think of FPS games. Althought, the game adds nothing new to the already complex formula, it does adds smoothness to the game core mechanics and the fast paced arcade-style shooter, ranking & rewarding as well as unique kill streak system in which skillful players shall go on a rampage quite easily with the aid of air supports or ground fire powers.The thrid entry to the series does not dissappoint because the single player campaign is filled with action as well as intense sequences. The story is well written and completed the story in a consistent and well told narrative. It also did a great job on connecting all the previous games together while maintaining twists that will keep the player guessing with unpredictably deep story. The story mode does not have a good replayability unless you are a collection fanatic that will be interested in perfecting the game with enemy intels, other wise I'd say it is not worth the hassle. The music score is an honorable mention here as the composer Brian Tayler has really hit the score with the music on the battlefield as well as the impact of guns and bullets hitting different places. The sound track is overall excellent not only does it set a atmospherical environment but it also connects the emotional link between the players and the characters and maintaining this link is what gives us the reason to care about the characters.In terms of multiplayer, the same formula applies. It is still addictive and still fun as new weapons and maps being added but the only down side to that is that additional DLCs will cost a fortune. Overall I will recommend this game to all FPS lovers and action gamers in general.

number of helpful: 8 of 9 people (89%) found this review helpful3 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: April 18, 2016
												This was one of the last decent Call Of Duties before they took off (Literally) with the jump packs and Halo jumping nonsense. To me this is a real Call Of Duty and it plays exactly how an arcade shooter should in most ways. This is the last COD with pro perks, a feature that they removed for unknown reasons. Probably because players are too lazy to shoot down 40 killstreaks or destroy 50 enemy equipments (Lazy buggers). The guns in the game aren't at all balanced, but that's what makes it fun, how you ask? Well I will tell you how. There's nothing more satisfying than dropping a M.O.A.B against a full party of MP7/ACR using tryhards with an underpowered weapon. Recoil isn't really a problem on this game, 1 or 2 guns present a mini challenge but anyone with a brain knows how to pull down slightly with the mouse. The 3 killstreak options made this game very fresh and added numerous different playstyles to the game. The noobs get rewarded even if they die if they opt for the support package. Moab hunters get rewarded when using the specialist package. And the diehard MW2 fans get rewarded for using the Assault package. The killstreaks aren't that powerful in the assault package, nowhere near as good as MW2 but it can still be fun to use from time to time. Most of the maps on Modern Warfare 3 have decent design and stick to the same formula that was used on Modern Warfare 2. They promote rushing and movement most of the time and they try to stay small so you won't be caught looking for a gunfight for too long (Unlike Ghosts. Yuck). However, some players still insist on using Thermal LMGs in the most annoying ways. There are quite a few clans that scour TDM using this strategy. LMGs combined with a campy playstyle is almost impossible to beat considering they're deadly accurate with thermal. I would personally consider them to be overpowered. Almost everything has some sort of counter-play, minus the C4. If you have blast shield on and it's right next to you. You're dead, no questions asked, same thing with claymores and Bouncing betties. Your only saviour is a ballistic vest and this means you will have to play using the support package which is heavily looked down upon by most players.Quickscopers and proper snipers are a pain on this game yes, but you will find yourself surviving a shot from them quite often (If you really hate them, ballistic vests make sure you're always a 2 hit kill, even to the head!) however, a decent quickscoper can outclass any gun at any range and it makes things quite unfair. Quickscopers can easily outclass a shotgunner/SMG at close range which never makes any sense, but then again there are tonnes of things which don't make sense in COD, like another age old problem of shooting first, hitting them a tonne and somehow dying first? That's the problem with the extremely low tickrate that COD has. If we could have a tickrate above 100 then things would improve drastically. Or would they?The online support for this game is where things begin to go sour very quickly. Hackers are allowed to roam free and there are some days where you begin to forget what a normal lobby even looks like. You can run into the same hacker for months on end and report him everytime and nothing will be done, the report button is like the pointless button from ASDF movie. If you leave say a TDM lobby and go back to search for a TDM lobby, you will often find yourself back in the exact same lobby, this is another frustrating feature. Also there's the age old problem of joining a game where your team is losing by 60 kills and there's no way you will win and it goes against your Win loss ratio. Many players take pride in their W/L but most of the time there's nothing you can do to save it. Kicktool abusers are exactly what this game doesn't need and they're everywhere! This tool was released so the MW3 community could combat hackers by kicking them, but now it's used by good/bad players to kick decent players from the lobby so it's easy for them. Bad players end up thinking everyone who kills them has some sort of hack because of their God complex. Whilst the good players (With the hacktool) have no honour and kick the other good players as soon as they see their KD in danger.To conclude my review, I must admit that this game has been a lot of fun over the years and was definitely worth the £30 I spent back in the day on it. But it's not worth that now at all. The DLC is dead, half the multiplayer modes are empty, and the player base is dwindling. You will be lucky to reach above 100 hours before growing to hate the game and quitting it, never looking back again. Rightly so, Activision and co never continue supporting their older games and that's their downfall, it's sad but unfortunately it's a way of life. Why generate a loss by appeasing the players that remain on the old CODs when you can 'appease' the players on the newer CODs and continue generating revenue? I digress, time for the ratings out of ten.Multiplayer: 6/10 - It's broken and there's no denying that.Campaign : 7/10 - It kept to the MW formula that made the other MW games fun.Special ops/survival etc : 5/10 - I found myself getting bored instantly with both Spec ops and survival. They effectively copied MW2s spec ops, just badly.Overall: 6.5/10 - This is a very fun game If you can look past all the hackers, kick tool abusers, campers, overpowered weapon abusers and headglitchers. It still isn't worth the price tag however. £20 sounds more reasonable. Thanks for reading.

content:

												This is my 1st game in the Call of Duty® series, that I have played. I was amazed how good it is. I was a fan of MOH, but man ... this is Counter Strike "on steroids": so much fun in multiplayer, epic singleplayer, active and fun community and so many modes you can have fun with. It runs on my comp on extra at 1920x1200 and it runs flawlessly, and I can't say this about BF3, so for me Call of Duty®: Modern Warfare® 3 it's the best shooter of 2011, and I think no game can take this title fom him. 10/10.

content:
Posted: December 18, 2013
												Call of Duty: Modern Warfare 3 is a first person shooter game from Activision. Call of Duty: Modern Warfare 3 is a sequel to the previous game, Call of Duty: Modern Warfare 2.Call of Duty: Modern Warfare 3 continue the story from the previous game. The single player campaign only has new storyline, but the gameplay are mostly the same, go to objective A, then go to objective B to destroy objective C. The Special Ops game mode made a return in this game with new missions. Call of Duty: Modern Warfare 3 also introduce the new survival game mode that you can play cooperatively with friends. The survival mode is quite interesting part of the single player game. The multiplayer of Call of Duty: Modern Warfare 3 doesn't change much also.Call of Duty: Modern Warfare 3 has quite improved graphics from the previous game, but doesn't have revolutionary upgrades, just small improvements. The water shaders are basically the same, I'm not even sure if those are shaders. Weapons models and characters has some improvements and changes in details. Performance are somewhat good, but not that good compared to the newer Call of Duty: Black Ops 2, which on the same system has far better performance. I sometimes got very heavy stutters which lead to crash to dekstop.Call of Duty: Modern Warfare 3, while not being a great sequel, the survival single player game mode is interesting to play, especially on cooperative. I still recommend this.Rating 6/10

number of helpful: 12 of 18 people (67%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: September 19, 2015
												The only reason I own this game is that I got it as a gift from someone else.Now, had COD4 and MW2 not already existed, I might be a little more enthusiastic about this game. I will admit that despite the blatant rehashing of MW2 assets (models, textures, even the bloody HUD), the campaign was entertaining enough to keep me going from start to finish. Soap and Price are both badasses. The scripted destruction events are admittedly well done and immersive. The weapons pack a lot of punch and feel satisfying to use. The plot, while predictable, is sufficiently intriguing and isn't riddled with cheesy dialogue. Still, it can't compare to the first Black Ops, which had quite a memorable campaign that I truly enjoyed.Unfortunately, the multiplayer, which was what kept me coming back to previous COD games, proved to be the same letdown that MW2 was.No dedicated servers if you want a ranked game. On a PC platform where latency is very noticeable thanks to everyone using a hyper-responsive keyboard and mouse, this is unacceptable. If everyone's connection is decent, then the experience is tolerable but still inferior to that of a dedicated server. Especially when a game supports up to 18 players, who don't necessarily all live in the same geographic region. It's most annoying when host migration occurs due to someone ragequitting or just experiencing an Internet blackout. There's a reason why even some co-op games like Left 4 Dead use dedicated servers despite the considerably lower player count - the performance is just so much better that way!COD also pretty much kickstarted the modern trend of charging $15 USD for a handful of maps as DLC, instead of letting the community make their own custom maps. Now, paid DLC isn't necessarily a bad thing. After all during the CD-ROM days we were happily buying expansion packs for games, which were smaller than sequels but added a great deal of extra content that made the price worth it. Starcraft Brood War, the original Half-Life expansions, Command and Conquer Generals, etc, all would qualify as "worthwhile DLC". However, COD's DLC is nothing but level geometry that any dedicated modder could slap together in his spare time. It's not an expansion pack and not worth it at all. At least when Overkill Software (Payday 2) does DLC, they allow non-owners to access the DLC if the server host owns it ,which keeps the community together. Not exactly my cup of tea, but a lot fairer than the COD DLC model that has sadly infected Battlefield and other once-great series.Garbage games like MW3 don't even deserve to be pirated. Pirating the game would send a message to IW/Activision that the product is popular/desirable. Unfortunately, looking at current trends COD is going to be here for a very long time.

number of helpful: 25 of 43 people (58%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: October 27, 2014
												I wrote a review last week but my internet disconnected when I clicked "post review." Because of that, I am going to make this redo a too long, didn't read version.Call of Duty: Modern Warfare 3 is what you expect from the Modern Warfare series but with a more Transformer approach to it. Anything and everything will be done over-the-top and there are explosions everywhere. The single player is very cheesy in the storyline and does not bring anything new other than an all out war. It's extremely bland and has repetitive levels. The opposite happens in the Special Ops, where there is indeed some improvements. There is more co-op missions and a survival wave mode added. Not a bad addition to the game at all, however, it does use a ranking system in order to unlock new weapons. Multiplayer is the same as usual but with new maps and the reintroduction of the game list first seen in MW1. Guns have more attachments. Attachments have gotten a redesign that has reduced the size of the reticle, allowing a player see more and thus kill more. However, they have also increased the "recoil/flinch" when getting hit by an enemy. Previously when hit, the reticle jumps a little bit; now it jumps, I estimate, 1/4 to 1/5th of the total screen size. This means that, when hit, you will not be able to kill your enemy because you will be aiming into the sky. Overall, Call of Duty: Modern Warfare 3 is an ok sequel and finish to the story of Price. It brings a some old, some new features back.Obligatory Score: 7/10* * * Did a bit of searching and found my original review as it did not post correctly to Steam. Here it is, in all its glory. Originally posted on 24 October 2014 * * *Call of Duty: Modern Warfare 3 is the first time I've played a Call of Duty game and though "wow, this is so stupid." I have played the first two games in the series and was finally able to get this a year after finishing Modern Warfare 2. In comparison, both games are highly similar in that the textures, storyline, voice, multiplayer, etc are all the same but with some tweaks. Modern Warfare 3 brings a continued storyline, a different style of Spec Ops, more guns and attachments, and the return of matchmaking. The storyline is what I hated the most out of anything. It's so over the top and "Transformers"-like, where anything and everything will be cliche and filled with explosions. Every level is pretty much a repeat the of the last and it gets boring, fast. Spec Ops is revamped so that there's a bit of variety and not just the challenges from Modern Warfare 2. There are plenty of guns as in the last game and many have been improved to look better, however, recoil, when hit, has gone up by a lot. When playing on hardened or veteran, the huge jump in aim when hit pretty much means you are going to die.Overall, the game is just an updated Modern Warfare 2. That's really all it is. Modern Warfare 3 is still fun, but the storyline is too over-the-top.Obligatory Score: 7/10

content:
Posted: July 13, 2012
												Two years ago, I wrote a quick review. Now, I want to expand it.Modern Warfare 3 takes where the previous game left you. Soap, the hero of Modern Warfare and the captain of the former Team 141, is badly wounded. Price and him escape thanks to Nikolai but you're followed by the fanatics under Makarov's order. Makarov? He's a mad Russian terrorist, an ultra-nationalist that attacked his own people in an airport to trigger a war against USA - though Shepherd, the general commanding Soap's unit isn't really a stranger to that. Anyway, after Shepherd's betrayal and death, Price and Soap are considered as war criminals. But it doesn't mean that they're going to stay without searching to clear their name. They're helped by Yuri, a man that hates Makarov with a passion. And during that time, Frost, a US soldier, will also participate to the battles of his life in USA and Europe....To understand the settings of Modern Warfare, it's strongly recommended to play Modern Warfare and Modern Warfare 2 as you'll find characters appearing in all these games. Or also just to understand the background.Modern Warfare 3 will make you play Soap, though briefly, Yuri, the Russian that will follow Price and Soap into their missions, Frost, battling against Russians in USA and Europe and under Sandman's command - Sandman being an ancient member of Team 141, Harkov, a Russian bodyguard for the President, Burns, a SAS member pursuing terrorists in London and Price for the last mission of Modern Warfare.As usual, the goal is to make sure your objectives are done, without being killed (you don't have an health meter, so the only way to survive is to retreat and let the screen coming back to normal), with  people to protect. You're not alone, you always have friends with you (Soap and Price when you're Yuri, Sandman and his squad when you're Frost, etc..).True, it's a Call of Duty, so don't expect anything making a full use of your brain (only when you need not to be spotted). And I still don't like a too nervous gameplay but you're getting used to it. Though good luck in Veteran...However, the places you're visiting are really great: from Paris to Berlin by New York or Siberia...A Call of Duty wouldn't be a Call of Duty if you don't loose some teammates or get your own character killed (will you be surprised that Makarov is also behind some kills?). The most shocking death will surprise you because you never thought that he would be killed off. Call of Duty, it's like the Walking Dead (the comic) or Games of Throne: you never know who will be killed or spared.The graphics are marvelous. The music is badass.And you still have the mode where you can play alone or with a friend.Modern Warfare 3 is really a good Call of Duty. Not really innovating, but the war seen by different points of view, knowing that each mission is tied to the previous one (ex: Price, Soap and Yuri got information, they've relayed it to the right people and Sandman and his squads are assigned on a mission based on that intel).Oh yeah, the multiplayer? I don't play. No way. The CoD community is too... competitive to my tastes.Go ahead, you can buy it eyes closed.... if you own MW and MW2. Else you will never understand the universe unless you read all the facts on the wiki.

content:
Posted: August 11, 2014
												I finally got to play this a couple years after watching an epic demo at the launch of the game, it was the level in the London underground and I couldn't resist playing a war game in such familiar locations, like the actual London, Berlin and Paris but I had to wait for the mac port and a bundle price drop. In the meantime I played all the rest of the series and when I got to MW3 and was playing through the chaos of this WW3 modern mayhem I was increasingly afraid that the campaign would end prematurely (like in the MW series) when you start getting infiltration missions in random bunkers outside of the main cities where the action takes place. And it did, the campaign seems shorter than the one in MW2, which I didn't think was physically possible. I runs only about 7h on 'hardened' and doesn't have much versatility. Sure SPEC OPS is now fully fleshed out with missions that run parallel to the storyline (saving Elena, playing bomb squad in Berlin like in 'The Hurt Locker', covering your team mate with air support while he advances on the ground) but most of the gameplay is straight point, shoot, cover with very little strategy. The original COD games were about securing zones so that your troops could advance and take over the cities from the Germans in WW2, you felt you were progressing through the geography and everything felt grounded and cohesive. Here you're just running like crazy from checkpoint to checkpoint and everything seems rushed. Ultimately the game feels like a missed opportunity because imagining a WW3 scenario with similar mechanics of the original would have been grand (you get glimpses of it while covering in between tanks in Berlin or advancing through Paris) but the game remains as superficial in gameplay as in storyline. I'm well aware that many just purchase the game for the multiplayer, and shooting each other in the those city maps sure is fun, but if only the game was as good as it's marketing it would be truly spectacular.PS: Also Spec ops is not Mac/PC compatible (MP is obviously), which means mac gamers will have an almost impossible time finding a partner. Aspyr ported Bordelands 2 and it's cross-platform, not getting this mode right for all COD series really sucks.

content:
Posted: August 12, 2015
												Call of Duty Modern Warfare 3 uses a less appealing version of the graphic engine used in Call of Duty Modern Warfare 2.The spawns in the multiplayer makes the game impossible to play, you can never be certain that your back is secured. You can not rely on simple tactics like securing an area. The entire game franchise went from epic battles with realism in mind to a constant intensive scene in an Arnold Schwarzenegger movie. Distances and weapon damages makes it impossible to move around in groups, rather forcing everyone to be a lone wolf running around like a complete maniac. The game franchise went down the hill after the release of Modern Warfare 2, and it has continued to fall ever since. There is much more to be said, how 95% of enemy contact is within a 5 meter range, or that they suck your wallet dry with unrealistic "gun skins" and rushed expansion packs. But the worst thing would be the maps. They are an everlasting Labyrinth of confusion. And why are the maps located at a mall, why would 18 special operation soldiers fight over a shopping mall?We who remember the epic desert battles on the Toujane map in Call of Duty 2 can comprehend what todays kids are missing out on. And, of course, the majority of the players are 8-12 year old kids who screams in the microphones and does "trickshots".

												I can't say much about this game. Other than it's shabby storyline that sucked, there were little bits I liked. The survival was pretty okay, it didn't wow me. The Spec ops missions were slightly good, kinda changed how it was played. I still don't get why Infinity Ward make you play as mute characters right until a cutscene (e.g. In Black Ops, Alex Mason talked in between points and not just the cutscenes and even say little bits like "Tango Down" or "FRAG OUT!!"). The scene after the friend dies [for reasons of spoilers, I'm not saying who], Yuri is grabbed by Captain Price and he demands to tell him about Makarov and Yuri does not talk until the cutscenes happen. It's a big WTF to me. So no, I don't recommend this game. You're better off playing the classic Call of Duty games.

content:
Posted: September 5, 2016
												TLDR: Its okay, more like a drawn out ending to MW2 rather than a progressive step forward. Overall: 7/10 Campaign, 4/10 multiplayerHere's a summary of the campaign without spoilers:-play as Delta-hide behind tanks, shoot stuff in the street-call in airstrikes-repeat-objective completed, cutscene-play as TF 141-go in stealthy-cover blown, go loud-repeat-objective completed, cutsceneMultiplayer: Few people play it, and the ones that do are using aimbots and some kind of auto-killstreak hack. There's no legit competition and no fun to be had there.Spec Ops: Decent and adds a few extra hours of playFull Review:There aren't really any alternative FPS games that come as close to a cinematic war experience as the CoD franchise. However, that's not to say Activision hasn't gotten lazy. MW3 improves on very little from MW2. In fact, many of the games resources and gameplay/map elements are blatantly recycled from CoD4 and MW2; to make up for this, the devs added several shiny atmospheric effects like jet fly-bys and national landmarks in the background to give the player a sense of large-scale battles/importance. Character development hardly exists in this one; it doesn't attach you to new characters and relies heavily on prior knowlege of events in MW2 and the relationship between Price and Soap. Yuri gets a small bit of background time, but you never really get to know Delta and that's where the devs missed an opportunity for a real impactful emotional experience. Its still fun to shoot bad guys and see large objects get blown up though, so buy it on sale if you've played MW2 and want closure.

content:

Before I provide my reasons for not recommending, let me provide you a solution to both Multiplayer & Singleplayer FOV:As Infinity Ward has ditched the ability to let us bind keys for commands such as FOV, Viewmodel positioning, No HUD, Noclip & such entirely from all modes of play (Unless you "inject" a custom program that enables Developer Console support, which I haven't managed to get working, so I'm not able to recommend it), there's now the MW3 FOV Changer, which gives you the ability to adjust FOV from 65° (Default) to 100° for both Singleplayer & Multiplayer equally. Instructions are simple: Just boot up the MW3 FOV Changer tool, launch the Main Game or Multiplayer from it, and whatever FOV you set it to in it's range, will always be played in the game. You can use the Numpad keys to adjust it in game manually if you desire, but simply typing your choice FOV (90.00 for example) will instantly apply in-game.This should not get you VAC-Banned, as Infinity Ward officially condones it's use: https://community.callofduty.com/thread/200397140#205674719I'd like to once and for all give Infinity Ward's stance on this subject.We do not mind if a PC user has the FOV changer mod.We also do not ban anyone that is using the FOV mod.EDIT: Just had confirmation that Valve also does not issue bans for FOV changer.You can download the tool from it's source here: http://www.mapmodnews.com/filemgmt/index.php?id=281And this video will demonstrate how to use it in seconds & spend about 2mins demonstrating it's effect: 


YouTube™ Video: MW3: Multiplayer Field of View Changer Tutorial 

			Views: 105,064		

			http://www.twitch.tv/ohamizzi Infinity Ward has declared the FoV changer as allowed and also VAC-safe ! Multiplayer and singleplayer download: http://www.mapmodnews.com/filemgmt/visit.php?lid=283		

Right, with that cleared up.My ReviewOnce upon a time, a friend kindly lent me his Xbox 360 copy of this game for me to try. I played through the singleplayer, and finished it bored out of my mind minus a couple of laughs here & there. And unable to log into multiplayer due to needing a Call of Duty Elite account (If I recall that correctly), I never even got to try what I wouldn't play anyway with Modern Warfare 2's multiplayer mess very much in mind. I thought I'd never spent a penny on this game in my lifetime.But it turns out, I did. I found other value for the game on PC, notably in the extractable audio files, so I bought it & did my thing. Then, many months later, I decided to see if there was any PC specific features to give it merit like the Developer Commands did for Call of Duty 4 & Modern Warfare 2. Turns out, there isn't (Without third-party tools I haven't figured how to get working), although the FOV Changer tool makes it very playable for me as someone who gets eye-strain & headaches within minutes due to the limited 65° default FOV.It also runs well, it's visually satisfactory & I like the improvements in sound assets & design where it's been made.SingleplayerSo I played the singleplayer again. And I remembered why throughout the entire singleplayer, I was bored throughout. The sheer absence of novelty. Infinity Ward does essentially repeat Call of Duty 4's playbook a third-time, and forces in notes from Modern Warfare 2's playbook, which in itself followed Call of Duty 4's playbook while cranking it to 11. Although Call of Duty does often make for good dumb fun, this in particular was so dumb it was numbing.And such repeated "stunts" including watching a child dying, just to try to get that controversial factor "No Russian" got, falls completely flat on it's face. And on occasions where civilians enter gameplay to be a gameplay obstacle, they quite often are in enemy & ally's firing line and simply get mowed down by both anyway. I'd say how I found this rather distasteful (As well as pointless on numerous occasions), but I think it's better to state this as an example to the laziness in design behind this game, even when taking into account Infinity Ward was having staff troubles due to the Infinity Ward-Activision Lawsuit)I'm aware not many play Call of Duty for the Singleplayer, and have good reason to. But what has often made for good dumb fun, this time, it's just so utterly dumb it's unenjoyable. I personally consider it the franchise's worst single-player experience second to Call of Duty: Ghosts (Which I haven't played due to the fact I have zero intent on giving money to such an awfully running port).MultiplayerI can't offer much here. I never got access to it during my Xbox 360 play, and I'm not interested in trying now. I do hear it added some interesting game modes such as "Kill Confirmed", which did stick for future games and removed a number of trouble-causing perks such as Stopping Power. It takes very much after Modern Warfare 2, so if you did endup a fan of Black Ops' COD Points unlock system like myself, you'll probably be disappointed. I don't have anything further I can provide comment on.Spec Ops (Co-Op)I never gave this a try neither. I had my fun with Modern Warfare 2's Spec Ops mode, so I had no desire to jump into this again, even with the Horde-Mode like missions added into it.VerdictCall of Duty: Modern Warfare 3 is a game very much starved of novelty in comparison to it's predecessors & Treyarch's entries made before it. It was a game that bored me throughout every minute I played it.It may run well, be jam-packed with explosive visuals, crazy setpieces, grand audio assets, but there's just nothing here I haven't already seen before.Perhaps the Multiplayer & Spec Ops modes do infact hold more novelty & balance than I presume, but in the end, Call of Duty fans, there's plenty of far better entries in the franchise you could be playing instead, especially for the high-worth Activision maintains as long & relentlessly as it possibly can, until it does occasionly join a big Steam sale event or make it's own. So if you want this game, keep your eyes peeled for those sales.

content:
Posted: November 1, 2014
												This review is mostly for the single player component.The story started off engaging and fantastic (read: unbelievable but fun) in the first game, and became a little more ridiculous in the next. By this game, the story doesn't even make sense.It's as if someone thought up a bunch of neat things for a trailer, and then tried to weave them together with whatever half-baked excuse they could conjure.The entire campaign plays "like a movie", meaning it's bearable on a solid run through. There is no replayability in any campaign mission. No mission stands out as the "I want to play that one again" type (Even MW2 had a few of those). There are lengthy on-rails sections in every mission where you don't have control of your character, and are forced to listen to other characters talk at you while enjoying the beautifully constructed scenery.Ultimately, Modern Warfare 3 would make an average action movie, but as a game, it's forgotten that players should still actually play.
